title.narrative: Integrated PCB Management in Costa Rica

description.narrative: Reducir al mínimo los riesgos de exposición de los PCB en las personas y en el medio ambiente de Costa Rica, disminuyendo barreras y logrando gestión racional de PCB.

description.narrative: The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
Number of additional males benefitting from livelihoods strengthened through solutions for management of natural resources, ecosystem services, chemicals and waste
Total number of additional people benefitting from livelihoods strengthened through solutions for management of natural resources, ecosystem services, chemicals and waste
Manejo Integral de PCB en Costa Rica
independent political entity
Energy - policy, planning and administration
Minimize risks of exposure from PCBs to people and the environment in Costa Rica
Number companies trained and implementing the new regulatory guidelines

comment.narrative: No guidelines for PCB management in place
8 companies trained and implementing the new regulatory guidelines
All 8 public electrical sector companies are implementing good practices indicated in the Technical Guideline and are in the process of updating regularly their inventories

description.narrative: Number of inspectors enforcement officers trained to enforce national laws norms on PCB management

comment.narrative: Limited knowledge about PCB management among environmental inspectors
20 maintenance and other personnel at PCB holders trained in safe PCB handling 4 inspectorsenforcement officers trained to enforce national lawsnorms on PCB management

49 technical personnel from 8 companies have received training in information collection for the inventory and technical guidelines for best practices
The project implemented a consultancy to evaluate the PCB storage sites within the electrical sector companies Through this process of evaluation recommendations were made and proper practices were explained to the maintenance personnel

description.narrative: Number of environmental health and customs authorities personnel trained to monitor compliance of Stockholm Convention requirements and national norms

comment.narrative: Environmental health and customs authorities personnel do not have the knowledge and training to execute control and monitoring of the PCB stockpiles in the country

30 officials of the environmental health and commerce authorities trained to control the commerce storage transport treatment and final disposal of PCBs 1 Norm developed and validated 4 guidelines manuals developed by end of the project

The technical guidelines on environmental sound management of PCB were published distribuited and placed on Ministry of Environment website
Three officials of the Ministry of Environment were trained in the use of L2000 DX analytical equipment and the interpretation of the results Furthermore in 2016 a chemist of Ministry of Environment staff was sent to a Stockholm Convention Regional Center CETESBI in Sao Paulo Brazil for a specialized course in PCB management This same chemist also assisted to a transformer seminar organized by a private transformer management company ITECNA
The Norm on identification and elimination of PCB was approved by the Ministry of Health and by Ministry of Economy Industry and Commenrce and its waiting ministerial signature

description.narrative: Number of safe PCB management and disposal options

comment.narrative: The country has no centralized facility for treatment PCB contaminated transformers
At least one treatmentdisposal alternative interim storagetransfer station in operation at the end of the project

In December 2015 several companies with different technological alternative to PCB decontamination and elimination were invited to present their options in a workshop organized by the project for electrical sector companies
A public tender for decontamination and elimination of identified PCB inventory has been published and is in the process of being awarded The total amount to be destroyed is approximately 100 TM of oil equipment and contaminated wastes

description.narrative:
Quantity of PCBs liquids and solids destroyed in the project period 20132017
Quantity of PCB material safeguarded

comment.narrative:
1000 MT PCBs destroyed pre project through exports and incountry treatment
National inventory but outdated

1350 MT of PCBs liquids and solids disposed of in an environmentally sound manner
All known PCBs safely stockpiled

At 30 June 2016 1134 TM of oil and equipment were decontaminated The last report indicated 112 TM of oil and equipment were decontaminated and in the second semester of 2015 two companies decontaminated a total of 14 TM of oil and equipment
A public tender for decontamination and elimination of identified PCB inventory has been published and is in the process of being awarded The total amount to be destroyed is approximately 100 TM of oil equipment and contaminated wastes
An electrical maintenance company was hired to identify PCB contaminated equipment owned by public institutions As a first step 200 institutions were visited and information of equipment plates were collected and analyzed Then 70 oil samples were taken and submitted to an acredited laboratory in Canada SDMyers to be analyzed None of them contained more than 50 ppm of PCB
In an effort to verify the results of L2000DX analysis of potentially contaminated equipment that each company had we sent a total of approximately 600 samples to be analyzed by cromatography to SDMyers These results were very helpful in being able to define the equipment and oils that were included in the tender process presently being awarded

description.narrative: Awareness raising and communication
Number of Awareness raising and communications strategies developed

comment.narrative: Currently no awareness raising and communication strategy has been developed regarding PCBs and the risk it poses to the people and the environment
1 Awareness raising strategy developed and implemented with the main stakeholders electrical sector companies regulating institutions and general public

Printed material was designed as part of the communication strategy Materials such as poster and brochures with best practices of PCB management and sample taking This will be distribuited to all companies and public institutions involved in hazardous waste management compliance
Once the PCB Regulation has been approved and published some of the actions developed in the communication strategy will be implemented to reach the private sector PCB owners to incorporate them in the National PCB Inventory Recently the Chamber of Industries has met with this project coordination to implement an awareness raising strategy among its members

description.narrative: Number of workshops with populations living close to Interim storagetransfer station

comment.narrative: Physical location of interim storagetransfer station has not yet been determined and therefore no communication exists with potentially affected population

4 Community workshops carried out for population living close to the interim storagetransfer station to inform about the benefits of interim storagetransfer station in terms of environmental protection and technical safeguards put in place for the operation Regular workshops on a yearly basis as follow up this activity
Since the interim storage transfer station will not be built this output will not be completed

description.narrative: Environmentally sound destruction of PCBs and management of contaminated equipment
Environmentally sound destruction of existing PCB inventory

comment.narrative: There is no technically and economically viable alternative to exporting which needs to be developed in order for the PCB owners to complete the elimination process and fulfill the Stockholm Convention goals
A feasibility study completed to determine the best available technological alternative and the interim storagetransfer station options

Instead of completing a feasibility study to determine the most appropiate technology for destruction and considering that the technical options for such a small inventory are already available on the market in December 2015 several companies with different technological alternative to PCB decontamination and elimination were invited to present their options This activitiy broadened the PCB holders information regarding possible decontamination elimination alternatives
A public tender for decontamination and elimination of identified PCB inventory has been published and is in the process of being awarded The total amount to be destroyed is approximately 100 TM of oil equipment and contaminated wastes

description.narrative: National Coordination mechanism established among PCB holders and government companies in operation

comment.narrative: The only option for the decontamination treatment and disposal of PCB contaminated equipment and oils is through exportation to installations at very high cost
National Coordination mechanism operating

Steering Committee is active it holds annual meetings and the Technical Advisory Committee holds monthly meetings The National Coordination mechanism is made up of these two entities Project team complete including National Coordinator Technical Leader and three officials from DIGECA Dirección de Gestión de Calidad Ambiental

description.narrative: Number of agreements between PCBs holders to develop interim storagetransfer station

comment.narrative: No formal agreement exists among the 7 PCB holders in the country
Public Private Partnership developed for the interim storagetransfer station administration 1 agreement reached between interested parties regarding interim storagetransfer station operation

There were no agreements developed because of the change in the decision to not build an interim storage transfer station In its place the project coordination and technical team has worked closely with the companies in the implementing measures to upgrading their storage facilities to secure enviromentally safe management of their PCB contaminated oils and equipment
Another important aspect considered in the decision making process to not continue with the building of the interim storage transfer station was that the amount of PCB contaminated equipment and oils found is by far less than what was originally expected to be found It was decided that an direct decontaminationelimination process through a tender process was more cost effective

description.narrative: Number of feasibility studies to determine if low concentration PCB oils s can be destroyed locally

comment.narrative: Low concentration PCB oils cannot be destroyed locally and no study has been conducted to evaluate the feasibility
1 study to determine if PCB contaminated oils with less than 5000 ppm are destroyed locally where ODS will be destroyed

An initiative is being developed between the MINAE Ozone Protection Project and a cement company for the elimination of ODS There have been positive results and an open mind on the part of the cement company for ODS but the issue of PCB oil incineration for concentrations above 5000 ppm was directly addressed and they indicated that they would not be interested in anything but under 50 ppm disposal

description.narrative: Environmentally sound management and interim storage of PCBs
Interim storagetransfer station built and ready for operation

comment.narrative: No interim storagetransfer station in operation
1 Interim storagetransfer station in operation according to developed standards and national law

Adapative Management will be applied for this indicator since the Ministry of Environment has decided to not build a Transfer Station and instead will enhance the individual storage facilities for the electrical companies

description.narrative: Number of Designs for Interim storagetransfer station

comment.narrative: No design for interim storagetransfer station exists currently
1 Design for interim storagetransfer station developed according to international best practices

Adapative Management will be applied for this indicator since the Ministry of Environment has decided to not build a Transfer Station and instead will enhance the indicvidual storage facilities for the electrical companies

description.narrative: Number of Electrical sector companies with PCB management plans developed and presented to national authority for approval

comment.narrative: There is a lack of a national environmental management plan that includes an elimination plan so that electrical companies can use as guidelines for their activities regarding their PCB issues
PCB environmentally sound management practices implemented in at least 7 electrical sector companies

The project implemented a consultancy to evaluate the PCB storage sites within the electrical sector companies Through this process of evaluation recommendations were made and proper practices were explained to the maintenance personnel Based on the existing techincal guidelines and the consultancy recommendations the project will support with the purchase of some storage equipment container pallets and Emergency Response Equipment as well as paint sealants for storage floors

description.narrative: Number of Environmental Impact Assessments for Interim storagetransfer station

comment.narrative: No EIAs prepared
1 Environmental impact assessment developed and approved

Adapative Management will be applied for this indicator since the Ministry of Environment has decided to not build a Transfer Station and instead will enhance the individual storage facilities for the electrical companies

description.narrative: Number of Occupational health and safety guidelines issued and implemented by electrical sector companies

comment.narrative: Occupational health and safety issues are important when evaluating potential risk for workers who have already been exposed to PCBs in the past and to prevent future incidents
1 set of Guidelines and technical standards for management of PCB equipment established and implemented transportation storage management and disposal
The technical guidelines on environmental sound management of PCB were published distribuited and placed on Ministry of Environment website

description.narrative: Number of Technical standards developed for interim storagetransfer station

comment.narrative: No Technical standards for interim storagetransfer station have been developed
Technical standards developed and implemented according to national conditions for Interim storagetransfer station including design operation interim storage and management of hazardous substances

Adapative Management will be applied for this indicator since the Ministry of Environment has decided to not build a Transfer Station and instead will enhance the individual storage facilities for the electrical companies

description.narrative: Number of trainers trained on Best practices for PCB Management

comment.narrative: No trainers trained

1 set of national occupational health and safety standards for PCB management formulated for national application approved by regulating authority and in operation in electrical sector companies A minimum of 10 trainers trained on Best Practices for PCB management

For the second semester of 2016 training on Best Practices for PCB management will be given to specific groups such as Emergency Response personnel Ministry of Health inspectors and general electrical equipment maintenance companies

description.narrative: Technical standards for the environmentally sound management of PCBs approved

comment.narrative: No guidelines and technical standards are currently being used
7 PCB owners with management plans presented to regulating institution and compliance verified

The specific PCB Technical Guidelines that were publised at the beginning of 2016 are being implemented by the companies and are available on the Ministry of Environment Website
The PCB regulation that will be approved shortly has the new requirements that specific PCB management will require additional to the general hazardous waste management regulations that already exist The regulation states that these existing regulations are the basis for this new one The main elements of compliance are identification of PCB contaminated equipment and oils reporting of transformers and contaminated inventories in the informatoin system and the obligation to eliminate before 2028

description.narrative: Monitoring adaptive feedback outreach and evaluation
Number of high quality monitoring and evaluation documents prepared during project implementation

comment.narrative: No documents in baseline situation

4 Quarterly Operational Reports submitted to UNDP each year
1 annual APRPIR submitted to UNDP each year
1 Midterm evaluation
1 Final evaluation
MTE and FE must include a lessons learned section and a strategy for dissemination of project results

In place of quarterly reports bimonthly monitoring meetings are carried out 1 annual APRPIR is submitted
The MTE selection process was completed and in the process of completing the contractual requirements This evalaution will be completed in the second semester of 2016

description.narrative: Strengthened Institutional Capacity in Costa Rica for the environmentally sound management of PCBs
Number of inspections carried out during project implementation 201317

comment.narrative: Currently contaminated sites have not been identified The national inventory was done in 2005 and was based on out of service equipment and primarily with ClorN Oil testing
At least1 inspection made by inspectors to each electrical sector company per semester

In spite of not having the PCB regulation approved officials from the Ministry of Environment visited 8 electrical companies facilities during this period The visits aimed to discuss the recomendations given by the consultant for the improvement of the storage conditions

description.narrative: Number of inspectors trained to conduct site visits for the verification of compliance of the regulations for PCB management

comment.narrative: The regulating institution does not have trained inspectors that can evaluate the environmentally sound management of PCBs
At least 4 inspectors trained in PCB management evaluation and enforcement

In 2016 a chemist of Ministry of Environment staff was sent to a Stockholm Convention Regional Center CETESBI in Sao Paulo Brazil for a specialized course in PCB management This same chemist also assisted to a transformer seminar organized by a private transformer management company ITECNA
In total 3 officials from Dirección de Gestión de Calidad Ambiental DIGECA has been trained in general PCB management concepts the use of L2000 analytical equipment and sample taking

description.narrative: Number of PCB management regulations developed and validated by regulating institution

comment.narrative: PCB management is not established by regulations and norms that guarantee their environmentally sound management
PCB management regulations and environmentally sound management norms developed and validated

One regulation Regulation for the identification and environmentally safe elimination of PCB has been technically approved by the Ministry of Health cosigner and the Ministry of Economy Industry and Commerce Official signatures are in process and its publication is expected by December 2016

description.narrative: Number of potential contaminated sites Number of national inventories updated on line with information from electrical companies on contaminated equipment and oils identified and inventories eliminated

comment.narrative: Currently one annual report is submitted to the SC Secretariat
A preliminary inventory of potentially PCB contaminated sites PCB data base operating with on line reporting from electrical sector companies with inventory update information

A consultant company conducted a preliminary inventory of potentially PCB contaminated sites 8 electrical companies participated in the study 11 sites were studied in each one a hydrogeological conceptual model was developed 101 soil samples were taken and then analyzed by L2000 analytical method according to this screening method 6 of the samples have more than 50 ppm of PCB The results were presented in a workshop in December 2015 This preliminary study suggested that 6 sites could be contaminated further chromatography analysis should be made to confirm the results
An IT company was hired to design useful reports and to improve the PCB information system This project is in progress

description.narrative: Capacity building for mainstreaming MEA objectives into inter-ministerial structures and mechanisms
The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
Number of additional males benefitting from livelihoods strengthened through solutions for management of natural resources, ecosystem services, chemicals and waste
Total number of additional people benefitting from livelihoods strengthened through solutions for management of natural resources, ecosystem services, chemicals and waste
Mejorar capacidades para integrar los objetivos de los Acuerdos Multilaterales Ambientales en estructuras y mecanismos interministeriales
Energy - policy, planning and administration
To mainstream the international commitments derived from the Rio Conventions into targeted national environmental legislation

A targeted set of improved capacities to meet and sustain Rio Convention objectives is improved
Commitments under the Rio Conventions will have been strengthened and institutionalized
Existing national development strategies plans and programmes will better support a more harmonized approach to implementing existing environmental legislation

comment.narrative:
Capacities to implement the Rio Conventions are not sustainable requiring donorfunded projects
Commitments to implement the Rio Conventions are measured through Rio Conventionspecific instruments
National environmental policy instruments contain provisions that counteract each other and are weakly implemented

Rio Convention obligations are being better implemented through existing environmental legislation 15 increase in survey value response
A yearend analysis of environmental legislation shows an improvement in institutional responses to monitoring and enforcing environmental legislation for the Rio Conventions
There is a minimum of 20 increase in the understanding of the Rio Convention mainstreaming among government staff
There is a minimum of 15 increase in the appreciation of the Rio Conventions among the general public

Overall Project objective is on track In spite of delays in inception MEA focal meetings and strategic support for Costa Ricas National Biodiversity Strategy and Policy and National Contribution under the UNFCCC have allowed for a an improvement in the implementation of the Rio Conventions Institutional arrangements for crosscutting approaches are being developed through the strengthening of the Presidential Council for the Environment with line Ministries from Agriculture Transport Health Tourism among others

description.narrative: Crosscutting Rio Convention provisions are integrated into environmental legislation

21 Indepth analysis of environmental legislation and its governance
Roster of expert peer reviewers on the global environment created
Rio Convention analytical framework
Targeted analytical reports on environmental governance per the Rio Conventions
Stakeholder consultations on Rio Convention governance at the national level
Regional and nonstate representation in stakeholder constituent dialogues
Consensus agreements from MEA technical committee on recommendations for improved environmental governance

comment.narrative:
21 Indepth analysis of environmental legislation and its governance
There are many experts working on most if not all aspects of the Rio Conventions
There are many analyses pertaining to the Rio Conventions but most all are focused on reporting requirements
There are numerous stakeholder consultations but most all are either targeted to focal area or sustainable development objectives
Regional and nonstate stakeholders participate in many governmentsponsored consultative dialogues but these are nearly all very targeted to focal area or sustainable development interventions
Technical recommendations by the advisory commissions do not take into account similar technical recommendations by other advisory commissions

21 Indepth analysis of environmental legislation and its governance
A roster of peer reviewers with minimum 50 experts is created by month 3
Analytical framework prepared and completed by month 6
At least five 5 independent peer reviewers rate the framework of high quality
Four 4 indepth analyses targeting Costa Ricas environmental governance from a Rio Convention perspective completed by month 10
Synthesis analysis is endorsed by all members of the MEA technical working groups and the MEA technical committee by month 12
MEA technical committee drafts policy recommendations for the InterMinisterial Council by month 14
All reports are discussed and validated at openended stakeholder dialogues within two months of their completion
Each stakeholder constituent dialogue is attended by at least 30 representatives that cover the range of stakeholder views and perspectives
Each stakeholder constituent dialogue endorses the analyses and offers broad support for endorsement by the MEA technical committee and subsequent approval by the InterMinisterial Council
At least two 2 stakeholder representatives from each of the seven 7 provinces have participated in at least one of the stakeholder constituent dialogues by month 33
Roster of peer reviewers created Analytical framework for the analysis of environmental legislation and its governance currently being developed to be completed in year 2

description.narrative:
22 Learnbydoing integration of Rio Conventions into select environmental legislation
Three Rio Convention technical working groups established under the MEA Technical Committees
Draft agreement on information sharing see output 12
Modified enforcement of existing national environmental legislation per Rio Convention obligation
High quality progress reports and independent assessment of legislative reforms
Expert workshops convened to regularly assess conflicts between environmental legislation
Best practice and lesson learned reports

comment.narrative:
22 Learnbydoing integration of Rio Conventions into select environmental legislation
Technical working groups and workshops under Rio Conventions are not institutionalized by rather temporary organizational mechanisms under focal area projects
There is no formal or institutional agreement on the sharing of information across ministries agencies or nonstate actors
Numerous progress reports are prepared and submitted resulting in an overburdening of government staff and low commitment but these remain targeted to focal area priorities
Expert meetings do not adequately address the crosscutting barriers to effective implementation of national environmental legislation
Development partners in Costa Rica are committed to supporting the countrys improved access to better data and information on innovative approaches to meeting global environmental objectives

22 Learnbydoing integration of Rio Conventions into select environmental legislation
Three Rio Convention technical working groups are created and meet by month 7 of the project and at least twice 2x per year
Technical working groups present their findings and recommendations to the MEA technical committees by month and subsequently within one month of convening
Technical working group draft a nonlegally binding agreement on the mutual sharing of information among each other and with the government by month 12 of the project
Three policy recommendations piloted and completed by month 26
Government agencies and departments responsible for testing policy recommendations submit quarterly progress reports to the MEA technical committees every three months with the first no later than month 12
Two 2 expert workshops with at least 30 relevant key actors each organized and concluded by month 18
Three 3 best practice and lessons learned reports are prepared on targeted regional Rio Convention mainstreaming activities by month 12 month 23 and month 33
Technical guidelines are drafted and finalized by month 24
Policy recommendations to legitimize these guidelines as appropriate are prepared submitted and approved by the InterMinisterial Council by month 28

Three Rio Convention technical working groups set up These working groups have planned a series of intersectorial dialogues particular in climate change which is to be reported for year 2 The National Policy Framework on Biodiversity is also being discussed through stakeholder consultations and the results will be shared in the next reporting period

description.narrative:
23 Strengthened monitoring and compliance
Monitoring and compliance indicators
Monitoring and compliance assessment reports
Monitoring and compliance guidelines and tools
Policy decisions on legislative and institutional reforms to reconcile and harmonize environmental and related legislation to conform with Rio Convention obligations
Training workshops on monitoring of and compliance with environmental legislation
Number of relevant government staff having clear present and potential future roles in monitoring and compliance

comment.narrative:
23 Strengthened monitoring and compliance
There are no clear monitoring or compliance indicators to assess the extent to which Rio Convention obligations are being delivered through existing national environmental legislation
Monitoring reports are internal documents that have unclear value to planners and decisionmakers
Monitoring and compliance guidelines and tools are not widely known among planners and decisionmakers
InterMinisterial Council focuses on climate change but there is no equivalent policy decisionmaking mechanism that is as effective on biodiversity or land degradation
Trainings to take place on environmentrelated issues however these remain targeted to focal area issues with inadequate attention to environmental legislative reforms

23 Strengthened monitoring and compliance
Clear monitoring and compliance reforms submitted to the MEA technical committee after three monitoring phases by month 12 by month 23 and by month 33
Quarterly progress reports are submitted to the MEA technical committees every three months beginning by month 15
Lessons learned of pilot monitoring and compliance reforms discussed in a stakeholder constituent dialogue by month 22
Survey of Ngt100 experts and other stakeholders by month 22 and a second survey by month 33 rate successful piloting of monitoring and compliance reforms
MEA technical committee proposes monitoring and compliance reforms to institutionalize best practice monitoring and compliance procedures by month 32
InterMinisterial Council authorizes at least 80 of MEA technical committee recommended reforms by month 34
Report on guidelines tools and resources for the effective interpretation supervision and enforcement of environmental legislation completed by month 8
New guidelines tools and other resources are available through the electronic platform by month 12
Comprehensive training programme drafted by month 18 and endorsed by the MEA technical committees by month 20
Four 4 training workshops and related exercises begin by month 20
At least 80 government staff members that are directly implicated in the planning and decisionmaking process to monitor and enforce environmental legislation have participated in training workshops by month 33
Operational guidelines are drafted and finalized by month 24 and validated by month 26
Policy recommendations to legitimize these guidelines as appropriate are prepared submitted and approved by the InterMinisterial Council by month 28

Consultant hired to help design the monitoring and compliance system within MINAE for the implementation of the Rio Conventions Recommendations for reforms will be completed and submitted to MEA technical committee by Year 2

description.narrative: Integrated interministerial decisionmaking process for the global environment strengthened

11 Strengthened MEA technical Committees
Awareness and understanding of Rio Convention MEA technical committee members
Frequency of MEA technical committee meetings
Policy recommendations submitted by MEA technical committee to InterMinisterial Council
Technical recommendations submitted to line ministries and agencies

comment.narrative:
11 Strengthened MEA technical Committees
Advisory commissions exist as equivalents of MEA technical committee but they meet on an ad hoc basis and there is communication and coordination among them
There is some representation of nonstate actors in the advisory commission for biodiversity but not for the climate change or land degradation
The work of the advisory commissions does not effectively contribute to government actions doe to unclear attribution of responsibilities

11 Strengthened MEA technical Committees
Baseline survey of decisionmakers and planners awareness carried out with Ngt100 participants completed by month 4 of the project
Yearend survey of decisionmakers and planners awareness carried out with Ngt250 participants completed by month 32 of the project
Three 3 MEA technical committees CBD CCD and FCC are created by month 4 with a membership of expert stakeholder representation of at least 10 different stakeholders government NGOs academia private sector and civil society The technical committees will meet at least three 3 times per year
MEA technical committees submit policy recommendations to the InterMinisterial Council twice 2 a year the first by month 9

MEA technical committee has met three times during reporting period to approve annual workplan and set priorities for Year 1 of Project implementation National project coordinator presented partial workplan on consultations for the UNFCCC National Contribution to the Presidential Council for the Environment Two interministerial committee meetings were held on climate change with inputs from Project staff A National Survey on Climate Change conducted by UNDP Costa Rica under the LEDS Project has been useful as a baseline survey on the public perception on the need for policies for a low carbon and resilient development strategy in the country The survey included a sample size of 1203 persons in a countrywide telephone poll with a confidence level of 95 and an estimated margin of error of 28 Meetings with nonstate actors including private sector and NGOs have enable to identify weakness in the representation of civil society organizations in the current MEA governance structure which will require strengthening during year 2

description.narrative:
12 Strengthened information sharing agreements with academia and civil society
Baseline analysis of information needs for the global environment
Feasibility study for the strengthening of an electronic informationsharing mechanism
An informationsharing agreement signed by MINAE and key nonstate actors same as in output 22

comment.narrative:
12 Strengthened information sharing agreements with academia and civil society
Much data and information relevant to the Rio Conventions exists but for the most part is not in a form that readily lends itself to sharing electronically
Data and information is largely accessible on an ad hoc basis
There are multiple electronic sources of information but do not contain all useful data and information

12 Strengthened information sharing agreements with academia and civil society
Indepth baseline analysis substantively peer reviewed by at least 8 national experts and completed by month 5 of the project
Feasibility study for the strengthening of an existing electronic platform and internet interface prepared and completed by month 7
Independent assessment of the performance of the electronic information system as implemented under 351 by month 30
Agreement signed by MINAE and key nonstate actors on the sharing of information by month 18

Support provided to strengthen data gathering and information sharing arrangements under the MINAE National Environmental Information System Existing platform for information sharing will be strengthened and opened to a larger number of stakeholders The only focal point with a operational platform for exchange of information is the UNCCD The Advisory Commission on Land Degradation CADETI includes representatives from Academia NGOs Ministry of Agriculture and Ministry of the Environment CADETI reviews land degradation policies provide technical inputs into policy goals and review the effectiveness of existing practices to reduce land degradation More support to CADETI is planned for Year 2 of the project By end of Project we hope to support the development of a policy for open data for environmental information in Costa Rica

description.narrative:
13 Reinvigorated InterMinisterial Council meetings
Cooperative agreements on legislative oversight with InterMinisterial Council members and other line ministries
Meetings of the InterMinisterial Council
InterMinisterial Council supports MEA technical committee recommendations

comment.narrative:
13 Reinvigorated InterMinisterial Council meetings
There is no formal agreement among ministries to reconcile overlapping oversight of environmental and related legislation
The InterMinisterial Council only meets to discuss climate change issues

13 Reinvigorated InterMinisterial Council meetings
Key ministries sign relevant agreements by month 12
InterMinisterial Council meets twice 2 per year to discuss and approve MEA technical committee recommendations and before month 9
At least 80 of the MEA technical committee recommendations are supported by appropriate interministerial decisions by month 34

Two meetings of the interministerial committee for climate change have included in their agenda presentations from National Project Coordinator A presentation before the Presidential Council on the environment provided the political support for a crosscutting multistakeholder multisectoral consultation on Costa Ricas National Contribution to the UNFCCC Joint working groups between Ministries of Environment and Agriculture strengthened on livestock and climate change

description.narrative: Strengthened technical and management capacities

31 KickOff and Project Results Conferences
Oneday KickOff Conference to raise high profile of project
Oneday Project Results Conference to showcase lessons learned and best practices
Four 4 expert panel discussions on Rio Convention subthemes

comment.narrative:
31 KickOff and Project Results Conferences
The environmental movement in Costa Rica is relatively strong compared to other countries and there is an overall strong interest among the NGO community and population to learn about innovative opportunities to catalyze environmental action
Development partners in Costa Rica are committed to supporting the countrys improved access to better data and information on innovative approaches to meeting global environmental objectives

31 KickOff and Project Results Conferences
Oneday KickOff Conference is held by month 3
Oneday Project Results Conference is held by month 34
Over 200 participants attend both the KickOff and Project Results conferences representing a good diversity of stakeholders including representation from other regions of Costa Rica
At least four 4 expert panel discussions present the lessons learned to deliver Rio Convention obligations through existing national environmental and related legislation
At least 30 participants attend each of the panel discussions

Oneday KickOff Conference held in March 2015 with high profile participation by Minister of the Environment Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs and UNDP Resident Coordinator National workshop on the UN Convention on Biological Diversity held in February paved the way for the finalization of the National Biodiversity Strategy and for the launch of the National Policy on Biodiversity

description.narrative:
32 Public awareness campaign survey and educational materials
Analysis of Costa Ricas environmental values survey results
Public awareness plan on national environmental legislation and Rio Conventions
Articles on legislative responses to implement Rio Conventions
High School competition plan
Education module on environmental legislation and Rio Conventions implemented
Public Service Announcement airings on television and radio that promote compliance with existing environmental legislation

comment.narrative:
32 Public awareness campaign survey and educational materials
Awareness and understanding of the Rio Conventions in Costa Rica is relatively good compared to other countries However this is not as effectively translated into compliance with environmental legislation further exacerbated by conflicting provisions of environmental and natural resource management legislation and regulation

32 Public awareness campaign survey and educational materials
Two broadbased surveys Ngt500 completed by month 3 and by month 34
Expert and independent analysis of the survey results completed by month 35
A comprehensive public awareness plan developed to completed by month 6
At least nine 9 articles on legislative responses for Rio Convention implementation in Costa Rica published in popular literature with high circulation before the end of the project By month 6 at least one article should be published By month 18 at least four 4 articles should be published By month 30 at least seven 7 articles should be published
Each article edited and published as a brochure with at least 100 copies each and distributed to at least two high value special events
High school competition plan for completed by month 9
At least two 2 high schools carry out high school competitions by month 20 at least six 6 by month 33
Education module prepared for high schools completed by month 8
At least two 2 high schools have implemented education module by month 20 and at least one high school in each of the seven provinces by month 33
One PSA completed for both television and radio audio version by month 12 with the first airing by month 15
At least 50 airings of the PSA on television and at least 100 airings of the PSA on radio both by month 34
No public awareness campaigns have been launched during the reporting period

description.narrative:
33 Awarenessraising dialogues and workshops
Awareness workshops targeted to the private sector journalists local and regional government representatives on national environmental legislation and the Rio Conventions
Survey data on environmental attitudes and values activity 321
Expert MEA legislative mainstreaming workshops complements learnbydoing workshops of output 22
Cuttingedge panel discussions by leaders in the environmental field on environmental legislation for meeting Rio Convention obligations

comment.narrative:
33 Awarenessraising dialogues and workshops
Media professionals generally have no special training of Rio Convention issues in particularly of the linkages between noncompliance of national environmental legislation and global environmental impacts
The private sector is primarily focused on traditional approaches to maximizing profits seeing environmental issues as an added transaction cost that reduces profits
Public dialogues take place through the construct of donorfunded projects on focal areas and do not adequately address the conflicting impacts on other environmental priorities
Regional government representatives are not adequately familiar with approaches to meet Rio Convention obligations given their heightened obligations to meet socioeconomic development priorities within their shortterm regional development plans
The general public in Costa Rica is generally aware and concerned about global environmental issues but increasingly behaviour is detached from these values due to increasing socioeconomic pressures and in the absence of innovative approaches to comply with existing environmental legislation

33 Awarenessraising dialogues and workshops
Three 3 panel discussions with at least 20 private sector representatives the completed by month 8 the second by month 18 and the third by month 28
At least three 3 journalist awareness workshops held each with at least 10 representatives the first completed by month 9 the second by month 19 and the third by month 29
By month 33 reporting on Rio Convention mainstreaming in the popular media shows a 10 increase over forecasted trends using baseline data and past trends
At least three 3 workshops of MEA legislative mainstreaming are convened with at least 20 expert practitioner participants the first completed by month 10 the second by month 20 and the third by month 30
At least three 3 regional workshops are convened with local and regional government representatives with at least one representative from each of the seven Costa Rican provinces having participated in at least one workshop Each workshop should be attended by at least 20 localregional representatives The first regional workshop should be completed by month 11 the second by month 21 and the third by month 31
Three 3 cuttingedge policy dialogues with invited leaders in the field of environmental governance the first dialogue convened by month 7 the second by month 17 and the third by month 27

Workshop held for the launch of the Campaign Clean your Footprint from the MINAE to help raise awareness of the need to reduce carbon emissions save wáter and reduce urban waste WOrkshop was held in the auditorium of La Nación a major national newspaper and attended by over 60 people including private sector NGOs reporters and journalists from several media

description.narrative:
34 Resource mobilization strategy
Resource mobilization strategy report
Feasibility study on financial and economic instruments to advance monitoring and compliance of existing environmental legislation to meet Rio Convention obligations
Expert working group established

comment.narrative:
34 Resource mobilization strategy
Costa Rica benefits from significant interest from the donor community to finance capacity development actions to meet global environmental objectives
Government of Costa Rica is very committed to taking a uniquely innovative and transformative approach to meeting Rio Convention obligations within existing environmental legislative frameworks to reduce the dependence of official development assistance which is not sustainable

34 Resource mobilization strategy
Analytical report drafted peer reviewed and finalized by month 12
Feasibility study on financial and economic instruments to advance the monitoring and compliance of environmental legislation for the global environment completed by month 18
Expert working group is made up of at least 20 rotating members who will undertake a desk review of the drafts of the analytical report and feasibility study and meet at least once to discuss the findings of each within one month of their completion ie by months 13 and 19

Meetings held with the new Country Focal point for the Green Climate Fund GCF A visit by the regional coordinator of the GCF was attended by national institutions private sector banking institutions and NGOs A resource mobilization strategy will be drafted peer reviewed and finalized during Year 2

description.narrative:
35 Internet visibility of integrated and streamlined environmental legislation
Website promotes Rio Convention obligations through existing national environmental and natural resource management legislation
Facebook page on environmental legislation for the Rio Conventions

comment.narrative:
35 Internet visibility of integrated and streamlined environmental legislation
There are a number of websites promoting environmental issues in Costa Rica However none are specific to environmental legislation MINAE is committed to strengthen a comprehensive website that will provide a onestop shop for understanding how to better interpret existing environmental and related legislation to meet both sustainable development and global environmental priorities
Development partners in Costa Rica are committed to supporting the countrys improved access to better data and information on innovative approaches to meeting global environmental objectives

35 Internet visibility of integrated and streamlined environmental legislation
Feasibility study for the creation of a comprehensive environment legislation website prepared and completed by month 4
Website architecture completed and endorsed by the MEA technical working group by month 6
Website is updated at least once a month with new information articles and resources
Website statistical data rank the quality of the website unique users visit sessions and page views as a consistent top ten site of all Costa Rican websites by the twelfth month of being online and throughout the projects three years of implementation
Facebook page created by month 3 and updated on a weekly basis at minimum
At least 2000 Facebook likes by month 32
Website development still pending Planned for Year 2

description.narrative: The project objective is to improve management in order to increase the conservation, sustainable use, and maintenance of the ecosystem services of internationally important wetlands.
Environment - policy, planning and administration

Área total (en hectáreas [ha]) de humedales protegidos de importancia internacional (HPII) dentro del SINAC Cambio en la eficacia de la gestión en siete (7) AP de humedales de importancia internacional medida con la herramienta METT Scorecard. Cambio en la capacidad financiera de once (11) AP de humedales de importancia internacional de acuerdo con lo establecido mediante el puntaje total promedio en la herramienta Sustainability Scorecard del PNUD/FMAM. Cambio en la representatividad ecológica (ha) dentro de once (11) HPII. Área total (ha) del área de los HPII demarcados y legalizados para propósitos de conservación y reconocida por los grupos de interesados durante 3 años. Cambio en la cobertura de la especie invasora Typha dominguensis en el HPII Palo Verde. Cambio en la tasa de invasión del pleco común (Hypostomus plecostomus), una especia invasora en dos HPII (Caño Negro y Caribe Noreste) Número de empleados (incluyendo mujeres) del SINAC y otras agencias nacionales y locales capacitadas en la protección y gestión de los HPII. Cambio en la brecha financiera (USD ) para cubrir los costos básicos de la gestión en once (11) HPII como resultado de nuevos mecanismos financieros. Ingresos anuales (USD ) para los HPII por tipo de mecanismo financiero implementado.

comment.narrative: Área total (en hectáreas [ha]) de humedales protegidos de importancia internacional (HPII) dentro del SINAC ? Aproximadamente 569724.00 ha Cambio en la eficacia de la gestión en siete (7) AP de humedales de importancia internacional medida con la herramienta METT Scorecard. ? Palo Verde: de un 47.4% a un 67.4% ? Térraba-Sierpe: de un 63.5% a un 83.5% ? Caño Negro: de un 57.5% a un 77.5% ? Maquenque: de un 39.5% a un 59.5% ? Caribe Noreste: de un 53.5% a un 73.5% ? Gandoca Manzanillo: de un 56.5% a un 76.5% ? Tamarindo: de un 56.5% a un 76.5% Cambio en la capacidad financiera de once (11) AP de humedales de importancia internacional de acuerdo con lo establecido mediante el puntaje total promedio en la herramienta Sustainability Scorecard del PNUD/FMAM. ? Marco legal, regulador e institucional: de un 31.15 a un 51.1% ? Planificación de negocios y herramientas para la gestión rentable: de un 18.6% a un 38.6% ? Herramientas para la generación de ingresos y su asignación: desde un 22.5% a un 42.5% ? Total: de un 25.0% a un 45.0%

12,063 hectáreas de HPII delimitadas, georefernciadas e incorporadas al SINAC, mediante el Catastro ABRE y publicitadas en el SNIT Política Nacional de Humedales elaborada y socializada Disponer de una Estrategia Nacional de Humedales, Viable, bajo implementación Delimitación de los once HPII sobre la base de la cartografía y ortofotos. El insumo a utilizar es el decreto de creación de cada uno. Elaboración/actualización de planes de Protección y control para los 11 HPII Elaboración de una guía o Protocolo para atender la amenaza específica de las especies exóticas invasoras Medición del impacto de las medidas aplivcadas para luchar contra las especies exóticas invasoras en los HPII Palo Verde, Caño Negro y Caribe Noreste Desarrollo de medidas específicas de adaptación al cambio climático para los HPII Elaboración de un inventario nacional de humedales

Para aumentar la representación ecológica de los humedales de importancia mundial, se elaboró una propuesta para incorporar 20 000 ha de humedales al esquema de protección.
Estamos impulsando un marco habilitado para mitigar amenazas a la diversidad en once (11) humedales protegidos de importancia internacional (hpii). Este año iniciamos la formulación de una política y estrategia nacional de humedales, su propuesta metodológica para y estamos avanzando en este proceso participativo.
El proyecto apoya la delimitación, georeferenciación e incorporación al catastro abre y SNIT de los once humedales protegidos de importancia internacional por medio de georeferenciación de las delimitaciones y elaboración de mapas en formato shapes.
Con respecto a la elaboración del inventario nacional de humedales se ha realizado coordinación con áreas de conservación que gestionan los hpii y la secretaría del SINAC, la elaboración de la metodología para la elaboración del inventario nacional humedales y la recolección de insumos a nivel institucional y áreas de conservación.
También se ha trabajado en la elaboración de planes de protección y control para 11 hpii e implementación para 7 hpii de planes de protección y control, así como de una guía o protocolo para atender la amenaza específica de las especies exóticas invasoras
Inicia la medición del impacto de las medidas aplicadas para luchar contra las especies exóticas invasoras en los hpii palo verde, caño negro y caribe noreste.
La eficacia de la gestión de siete (7) humedales protegidos de importancia internacional aumenta en un 20%, el programa de gestión local promueve la sensibilización y participación de los interesados y aumenta el entendimiento de los beneficios socioeconómicos y ecológicos y la importancia de los humedales en 7 ap para lo cual se ha elaborado un mapa de actores de los 11 hpii, una caracterización económica, social, ambiental e institucional de los 11 hpii y está en proceso de elaboración un sist

- 12,063 hectáreas de HPII delimitadas, georefernciadas e incorporadas al SINAC, mediante el Catastro ABRE y publicitadas en el SNIT - 11 HPII delimitados y georeferenciados - Planes de protección y control elaborados para los 11 HPII - Un protocolo para implementar medidas específicas para luchar contra cambio climático - Disponer de un protocolo para atender amenazas de especies exóticas invasoras - Un inventario nacional de humedales para el año 2019 - Al menos 50 funcionarios públicos capacitados sobre la importancia de los HPII

- 20,000 ha identificadas que potencialmente pueden ser incluidas como HPII -Estudios, delimitación física y mapas desarrollados para 7,000 ha en el Caribe Noreste y 4,000 identificadas en Terraba-Sierpe con 100ha ya mapeadas. - Los planes de control fueron asumidos por la contrapartida de Programa Costa Rica por Siempre. - Planes locales de manejo para el Caribe Noreste y Palo Verde, los mapas de actores fueron desarrollados para el resto de HPII - Sistematización de 10 años del canon de agua y estrategia para mejorar su implementación desarrollada como mecanismo de financiamiento para la inversión en HPII - Borrador Final de la Política Nacional de Humedales desarrollada, incluyendo un proceso participativo de formulación desde los Pueblos Indígenas - Respecto a la representatividad de nuevas HPII se contabilizan potencialmente 510 ha aguas abiertas, manglares y humedales mixtos del Refugio Nacional de Vida Silvestre Ostional; 10,000 ha,de pantano de Japdeva en el Caribe; 5,000 ha de bosques de palmas y mixtos para Terraba Sierpe; 9,000 ha de pantano herbáceo para Caño Negro; 720 ha de aguas abiertal al área marina de Las Baulas; Bosques de palma 1800 ha el humedal del Caribe Noreste, 1.137ha para la Laguna Corcovado como sitio Ramsar site; 2.400ha de manglares; Otras propuestas: 3.000ha incluyendo humedales y ecosistemas forestales Isla del Caño (300ha) e Isla Violin (1.000ha).

- 20.000 hectáreas de HPII delimitadas, georefernciadas e incorporadas al SINAC, mediante el Catastro ABRE y publicitadas en el SNIT - 11 HPII delimitados y georeferenciados - Un protocolo para implementar medidas específicas para luchar contra cambio climático - Un inventario nacional de humedales para el año 2019 - Al menos 50 funcionarios públicos capacitados sobre la importancia de los HPII - Reducción de un 19.4% o USD 2,541.196 al año de la brecha financiera para cubrir los costos básicos de la gestión de once (11) HPII como resultado de los nuevos mecanismos financieros -

The METT evaluations and the business plans done by Barreras project were revised in order for them to improve and be applied The scenarios have been analyzed in order to award nonessential services and business plans
METT evaluations were analized to know the indicators and to take into account in the planification process of the project
Regarding with the management we are developing a framework which includes a national policy on wetlands a national strategy on wetlands regional wetlands plans and specific wetlands management plans At the moment we have a conceptual and methodological scheme and a basic study on Costa Rica wetlands situation

description.narrative: National policy for the protection of wetlands

comment.narrative: This is a new project indicator The project analyzed the current political framework for the conservation of wetlands and identified the need for the development of a national policy to ensure the protection of this important ecosystem The project is already working on the policy and it should be approved in early 2016

description.narrative: Total area in hectares ha of IIPW within the SINAC

comment.narrative:
589742 ha
TérrabaSierpe is expanded by 5000 ha and other protected areas are expanded by 15000 and declared as RAMSAR sites

A proposal of new Ramsar sites or expanded current ones are drafted and under way to be approve by each SINACs Conservation Area because
1 The current politic instruction is not to create new protected Areas if there is not a participative process before hand with the population in the surroundings or directly affected by the wetland With that being said in Terraba Sierpe Wetland it is only possible to add 5000 HA as a Ramsar Ecosystem because those are the only ones inhabited and since the other ones are occupied and it is a participative process they are not going to agree to the terms and conditions
2 The project is looking to add approximately 15 000 ha as a wetland Ramsar that are currently wildlifeprotected areas but that have not been yet acknowledged as Ramsar ecosystem

description.narrative: Protected area PA system representation and emplacement of institutional capacity for the sustainable management and conservation of wetlands
Change in ecological representativeness ha within eleven IIPW

The project is developing the previous technical studies to
1 To acknowledge as a new IIPW approximately 510 ha of open water mangroves and mixed wetlands from Refugio Nacional de Vida Silvestre Ostional
2 To acknowledge as a new IIPW approximately 10000 ha of swamp forest from Japdeva in the Caribbean
3 Add approximately 5000 ha from palm forest and mixed wetlands to the Terraba Sierpe IIPW
4 Add approximately 9000 ha from Herbaceous swamp Ecosystem to the Cañ0 Negro IIPW
Potential Ramsar sites drafted and prioritized according to its ecological representatives provided that it will not only include the TérrabaSierpe expansion As a baseline a Ramsar wetlands preliminary diagnosis and map was done which will be discuss and validate in the SINACs CA

TThe Project established a training plan on IIPW topics it followed the General training Plan for the SINAC elaborated by the Barreras Project
The first training took place in the Caribe Noreste IIPW in June 2015 32 teachers from these regions were trained on the importance of wetlands 17 women and 15 men participated

description.narrative: Total area ha of IIPW area demarcated and legalized for conservation purposes and recognized by stakeholders by year 3

comment.narrative: TérrabaSierpe is expanded by 5000 ha and other protected areas are expanded by 15000 ha and declared as RAMSAR sites

The investment in equipment was necessary to achieve the demarcation and legalization of the IIPW
ARCGIS licenses for use in 11 SINACs CA were updated Related to this SINACs CA staff were trained in the use of a GIS tool ABRE as an instrument to improve management in the IIPW

description.narrative: Resources for sustainable management of internationally important protected wetlands increased and diversified

comment.narrative:
Vessel transit toll 0 Water consumption contribution TBD Waste water contribution 0
Tourism and other recreational fees 1442000 USD
Vessel transit toll TBD Water consumption contribution TBD Waste water contribution 0 Tourism and other recreational fees 3197250 USD

Baseline and target values for this indicators will be determined during the next few months The project will also be monitoring income derived from these incentives as soon as the proposed financial mechanisms are in place

description.narrative: Change in the financial gap USD to cover basic management costs of eleven 11 IIPW as a result of new financial mechanisms

comment.narrative: 65487762 USD 20132018 or 10914627 USD annually
52781782 USD 20132018 reduction of 194 or 2541196 USD annually

The project staff determined that the financial mechanisms proposed by the project document are not viable due to the following reasons a PES incentive for ecosystem conservation is mainly targeted to private land and is not suitable for the project sites and b REDD CNeutrality and Environmental Social Responsibility is still completing a preliminary phase and will not deliver a financial incentive by project closure This is why the project proposes the following measures to deliver financial incentives that are likely to decrease the financial gap of IIAPs by project closure a proposing a decree to ensure that vessels pay a toll when they enter the jurisdiction of protected wetlands b reforming the waste water and water consumption decrees to ensure that a percentage of funds paid by consumers is allocated to the conservation of wetlands
In addition the project is working on a conceptual and methodological framework for the valoration of the Eco systemic services that the IIPW offers to society
